SystemOutput:
Chief Complaint:

Fatigue, lightheadedness, and bloating.

History of Present Illness:

Brian is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for congestive heart failure and hypertension, who presents today for follow-up of his chronic problems. The patient reports feeling fatigued, lightheaded, and bloated for the past five weeks. He has been involved in home renovations and has had difficulty maintaining a healthy diet during this time. He denies fever, chills, chest pain, and shortness of breath.

Past Medical History:

Congestive Heart Failure
Hypertension

Physical Examination:

Jugular venous distention to 8 cm
Cardiovascular: Grade 3/6 systolic ejection murmur
Lung exam: Fine crackles at the bases bilaterally
Lower extremities: 1+ pitting edema

Vitals Reviewed:

Blood pressure, heart rate, and oxygenation are within normal limits.

Results:

Chest X-ray: Fluid in the lungs
Echocardiogram (4 months ago): Ejection fraction of 45%, mitral regurgitation

Assessment and Plan:

1. Congestive Heart Failure:
   - Medical Reasoning: The patient is retaining fluid, as evidenced by the physical exam and chest x-ray.
   - Additional Testing: Order another echocardiogram.
   - Medical Treatment: Increase Lasix to 80 mg once a day.
   - Patient Education and Counseling: Instruct the patient to weigh himself daily, call if there is weight gain or shortness of breath, and continue to monitor his diet.

2. Hypertension:
   - Medical Reasoning: The patient's blood pressure is well-managed at this time.
   - Medical Treatment: Continue Lisinopril 20 mg daily.
   - Patient Education and Counseling: Instruct the patient to continue recording blood pressures at home and report them through the patient portal if elevated.

The patient agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan. We will be in touch with the patient after receiving his test results.

CC:

Right knee pain.

HPI:

Ms. Thompson is a 43-year-old female who presents today for an evaluation of right knee pain. She states she was changing a light bulb on a ladder and had a stumble, twisting her knee while trying to catch her fall. The incident occurred yesterday. She has tried applying ice and taking Ibuprofen, but it does not help. She has a history of atrial fibrillation and takes Digoxin.

EXAM

Examination of the right knee shows tenderness over the medial meniscus area. Pain with flexion and valgus stress. Normal sensation in the lower extremity.

RESULTS

X-rays of the right knee show no obvious signs of acute fracture or dislocation. Mild effusion is noted.

IMPRESSION

Right knee medial meniscus strain.

PLAN

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I have recommended a knee brace and crutches for temporary use. She will follow up with me in one week, and if not improved, we will consider an MRI. I will prescribe Motrin, 800 mg to take every 6 hours with food for two weeks. She will follow up with me as needed if she continues to have pain. All questions were answered.

Chief Complaint:

Back pain.

History of Present Illness:

Logan is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis. He presents today with lower back pain after lifting heavy boxes on Saturday. He reports hearing a pop and experiencing stiffness since the incident. He has tried Tylenol, Ibuprofen, and Icy Hot, but these have not provided significant relief. He also reports tingling in his right toes, which resolved on Sunday.

Past Medical History:

Diabetes type 2, hypertension, osteoarthritis.

Physical Examination:

- Heart: Slight 2/6 systolic heart murmur, stable.
- Back: Pain to palpation of the lumbar spine, pain with flexion and extension, negative straight leg raise.

Results:

- Diabetes labs: Hemoglobin A1C elevated at 8.
- Back X-ray: Normal, good bony alignment, no fracture.

Assessment and Plan:

1. Back pain: Lumbar strain from lifting.
   - Medical Treatment: Prescribe Meloxicam 15 mg once a day, continue icing, avoid strenuous activity, and refer to physical therapy.

2. Diabetes: Slightly uncontrolled.
   - Medical Treatment: Increase Metformin to 1000 mg twice a day, repeat Hemoglobin A1C in 6 months.

3. Hypertension: Needs better control.
   - Medical Treatment: Increase Lisinopril from 10 mg to 20 mg daily.

4. Osteoarthritis: Stable, no further workup needed at this time.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Annual exam and follow-up of chronic problems.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ralph is a 62-year-old male with a past medical history significant for depression, hypertension, and prior lobectomy. He presents for his annual exam. Ralph reports that he has been managing his depression well with Prozac and has not had any incidents recently. He admits to struggling with hypertension and occasionally forgetting to take his Norvasc medication on weekends. Ralph also mentions experiencing shortness of breath with exertion during his morning runs, which are typically 4-5 miles long.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Ears, Nose, Mouth and Throat: Nasal congestion due to pollen.
• Cardiovascular: Occasional chest pounding during exertion.
• Respiratory: Shortness of breath with exertion.
• Psychiatric: Depression managed with Prozac.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Neurological/Psychological: Appropriate mood and affect.
• Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
• Cardiovascular: Slight 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Musculoskeletal: No lower extremity edema.

VITALS REVIEWED

• Blood Pressure: 120/80 mmHg.

RESULTS

Electrocardiogram: Normal.
Chest X-ray: Normal, no concerns related to prior lobectomy.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Depression.
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient is managing well with Prozac.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue Prozac 20 mg daily. Refill ordered.
   • Patient Education and Counseling: Encouraged to continue current management strategies.

2. Prior Lobectomy.
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient is exercising regularly and has good breathing function.
   • Medical Treatment: No further follow-up with the surgeon is needed.

3. Hypertension.
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient has improved blood pressure control but admits to occasional noncompliance with medication.
   • Additional Testing: Order an echocardiogram for the murmur.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue Norvasc as prescribed.
   • Patient Education and Counseling: Encouraged to maintain medication compliance and monitor blood pressure regularly.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right middle finger pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ms. Brooks is a 48-year-old female who presents today for an evaluation of right middle finger pain after a skiing accident. She reports that her finger was bent backward while skiing over moguls. The incident occurred four days ago. She has tried ice and ibuprofen for pain relief, but the pain persists.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Constipation, treated with Miralax.
Appendectomy at age 18.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

Examination of the right middle finger shows tenderness over the distal phalanx. No tenderness over the proximal joint or metacarpophalangeal joint. Pain with flexion.

RESULTS

X-rays of the right middle finger show no fractures and normal alignment.

ASSESSMENT

Right index finger contusion.

PLAN

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I recommend an aluminum foam splint for her finger and a prescription for Motrin 600 mg every 6 hours for one week. If the pain does not improve, she should call and return for a follow-up. All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Long-standing iron deficiency anemia.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Christina Cooper, a 65-year-old female, presents with a history of iron deficiency anemia since the age of 13. She reports recent fatigue, shortness of breath, wheezing, headaches, chills, and increased sensitivity to cold. She also mentions worsening anxiety and depression. The patient had a hysterectomy in 1996 and her last colonoscopy was 5-6 years ago with no significant findings.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

The patient is currently taking ferrous sulfate 25 mg twice daily and over-the-counter vitamin B12.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Respiratory: No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
• Cardiovascular: No murmurs, gallops, or rubs. No extra heart sounds.
• Gastrointestinal: No tenderness to palpation.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Christina Cooper is a 65-year-old female with a history of iron deficiency anemia.

Iron deficiency anemia.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient has been anemic since the age of 13 and has been experiencing fatigue, shortness of breath, wheezing, headaches, chills, and increased sensitivity to cold.
• Additional Testing: Schedule an upper endoscopy and colonoscopy to assess for potential sources of anemia or GI bleed. If inconclusive, consider capsule endoscopy.
• Medical Treatment: Continue ferrous sulfate 25 mg twice daily with orange juice for improved iron absorption. Recheck CBC, iron, ferritin, B12, and folate in 12 weeks.
• Referral: Refer the patient to a hematologist for further evaluation and management.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Follow-up of chronic problems.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Anna Mitchell is a 44-year-old female with a past medical history significant for arthritis, gout, and reflux, who presents today for follow-up of her chronic problems. It has been about 6 months since I last saw the patient.

The patient reports her arthritis is starting to get better. She has been trying to move her body with pilates and lifting weights. This has helped build up some muscles and her joint pain has reduced. The patient has also continued to attend physical therapy, which she feels has been beneficial.

Ms. Mitchell had an episode of gout of her right first big toe about 2 months ago. She states she is doing well on the allopurinol 100 mg once daily and has had no further flare ups.

Regarding her acid reflux, she was placed on omeprazole 40 mg once a day to help with some of the symptoms she was having. She started to make some dietary modifications, but she still needs to make more progress. She reports episodes of vomiting in the morning. The patient also has abdominal pain and bloating. Her last bowel movement was 2 days ago, and it was normal. She denies blood in her stool.

The patient denies unexplained weight gain or loss, fevers, chills.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Denies fevers, chills, or weight loss.
• Gastrointestinal: Denies hematochezia, melena. Endorses vomiting, abdominal pain, and bloating.
• Musculoskeletal: Endorses joint pain.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
• Cardiovascular: No murmurs, gallops, or rubs. No extra heart sounds.
• Gastrointestinal: Pain to palpation of the right upper quadrant. No rebound or guarding. No peritoneal signs.
• Musculoskeletal: Right knee shows a little effusion. Slight pain to palpation. Some decreased range of motion.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Anna Mitchell is a 44-year-old female with a past medical history significant for arthritis, gout, and reflux, who presents today for follow-up of her chronic problems.

1. Acid reflux with nausea and vomiting.
   • Medical Reasoning: She reports episodes of vomiting in the morning, as well as abdominal pain and bloating. She has been compliant with omeprazole and has made a few dietary modifications.
   • Additional Testing: We will order an ultrasound of her right upper quadrant, as well as additional labs, to rule out biliary etiology.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue omeprazole 40 mg once daily.
   • Patient Education and Counseling: I encouraged her to continue with dietary modifications.

2. Gout.
   • Medical Reasoning: Her flares are well controlled on allopurinol.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue allopurinol 100 mg once daily. This was refilled today.

3. Arthritis.
   • Medical Reasoning: She is doing well and has remained active since her last visit. Physical therapy has also been beneficial for her. Her right knee x-ray demonstrated residual arthritis but was otherwise normal.
   • Patient Education and Counseling: I advised her to continue pilates and using the knee. She will contact me if she has any issues and we can consider further imaging or intervention at that time.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Chest pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Betty Hill is a 59-year-old female with a past medical history of uterine fibroids and anemia. She is a new patient referred from the ER for esophagitis. The patient experienced chest pain for four days in early October 2020, which resolved on its own. She had difficulty swallowing during that time, but it has also resolved. She denies any recurrence of symptoms since then. The patient had a stressful job transition around the time of the chest pain.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain currently.
• Respiratory: Denies shortness of breath.
• Gastrointestinal: Denies abdominal pain. Endorses mild tenderness in the upper abdominal quadrants.
• Musculoskeletal: Denies joint pain or muscle aches.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Constitutional: In no apparent distress.
• Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
• Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs, gallops, or rubs. No extra heart sounds.
• Gastrointestinal: Mild tenderness to light palpation in the upper abdominal quadrants. No rebound tenderness or guarding.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Betty Hill is a 59-year-old female with a past medical history of uterine fibroids and anemia, presenting with a history of chest pain and difficulty swallowing.

Possible etiologies:
• GERD
• Dyspepsia
• Esophagitis
• Musculoskeletal etiologies
• Anxiety

Suspect she had an anxiety attack related to her job transition, plus or minus a contribution from musculoskeletal etiologies.

Plan:
• Discussed the option of EGD versus monitoring for symptoms. The patient elected to self-monitor her symptoms and will call with any recurrence or change.
• Follow up as needed for any other GI complaints.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Evaluation of kidney function in a patient with Smith-Magenis Syndrome.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Katherine is a 22-month-old female with a history of Smith-Magenis Syndrome. She is a twin and was born at 34 weeks and 3 days gestation. She has a history of feeding difficulties, reflux, and developmental delays. She is currently receiving feeding therapy, occupational therapy, physical therapy, and will soon start speech therapy. The patient has seen multiple specialists, including a geneticist, who mentioned the possibility of kidney anomalies associated with her syndrome.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Gastrointestinal: Patient has a history of reflux and feeding difficulties.
• Musculoskeletal: Patient has mild hypotonia of the lower extremities and arms.
• Genitourinary: Patient has 8-10 wet diapers per day, indicating adequate urine output.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• General: Well-nourished female, slightly fussy when examined.
• Eyes: Small appearing.
• Musculoskeletal: Mild hypotonia of the lower extremities and arms.
• Genitourinary: Normal external female genitalia.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Katherine is a 22-month-old female with a history of Smith-Magenis Syndrome. Given the potential for congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract associated with her syndrome, we will obtain a screening kidney ultrasound today. If there are abnormalities on the kidney ultrasound, we will determine next steps and future follow-up. The family lives in Dallas, Georgia, so her follow-up should be at the town center location.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right wrist injury.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Diana, an established patient, presents to the clinic with a right wrist injury sustained yesterday morning while doing laundry. She slipped on the stairs and tried to catch herself, resulting in immediate pain and swelling in her right wrist. She denies any previous injuries to this arm. The patient rates her pain as 9/10 and has tried ice, an Ace wrap, and ibuprofen for pain relief with minimal success.

PAST HISTORY

No significant past medical history.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

Ibuprofen as needed for pain.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Head, neck, heart, and lungs are unremarkable. Lower extremities show palpable pulses and no edema. Upper extremities show normal range of movement except for the right wrist. Pain on palpation, flexion, extension, abduction, and adduction of the right wrist. Patient is able to make a fist but not tightly. Swelling and bruising are present, with evidence of potential fracture and bony crepitus.

VITALS

Blood pressure: 140/70 mmHg
Heart rate: 80 bpm
Temperature: 97.2°F
Respiratory rate: 20 breaths/min

RESULTS
Imaging

X-ray of the right wrist shows a positive Colles' fracture.

ASSESSMENT

Colles' fracture of the right wrist.

PLAN

1. Provide a brace for the right wrist.
2. Schedule surgery for fracture repair as soon as possible.
3. Prescribe Ultram 50 mg every 6 hours for pain management.
4. Refer to physical therapy post-surgery for rehabilitation.
5. Follow-up appointment in one month to assess progress and discuss the patient's upcoming vacation plans.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right knee pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Philip Johnson is a 55-year-old male with a past medical history significant for hypertension, who presents with right knee pain.

The patient reports that he slipped and fell while working on his property about a week ago. He felt something pop in his knee during the fall. He has been experiencing pain when flexing and extending his knee, with a pain score of 4 out of 10. He has been taking ibuprofen for the swelling.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain or dyspnea.
• Respiratory: Denies shortness of breath.
• Musculoskeletal: Endorses right knee pain.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
• Cardiovascular: Grade 2 out of 6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Musculoskeletal: Pain to palpation of the medial aspect of the right knee. Pain with flexion and extension. Edema and effusion present.

RESULTS

X-ray of the right knee: No fractures or bony abnormalities.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Philip Johnson is a 55-year-old male with a past medical history significant for hypertension, who presents with right knee pain.

MCL strain.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient reports a pop in his knee during a fall, with pain during flexion and extension. Physical examination reveals pain to palpation of the medial aspect of the right knee, edema, and effusion.
• Medical Treatment: Prescribe ibuprofen 800 mg twice daily for pain and swelling. Provide a knee brace for support and recommend icing the knee for 20 minutes at a time, 3-4 times a day.

Hypertension.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient has a history of hypertension and is currently on 20 mg of lisinopril. Blood pressure was elevated at the visit (150/70).
• Medical Treatment: Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily.
• Specialist Referrals: Refer the patient to a nutritionist to help improve his diet and potentially reduce the need for medication.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left shoulder pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

The patient is a 39-year-old male who has been experiencing left shoulder pain for about three weeks. He cannot recall any specific injury but has been doing work in his basement recently. He has difficulty reaching for objects and lifting items, especially overhead. He has been taking extra strength Tylenol every 6-8 hours for pain relief, which only partially helps.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Non-contributory.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vitals: Reviewed and within normal limits.

Musculoskeletal:
- Left shoulder: Limited active and passive range of motion, tenderness of the greater tuberosity of the humerus, no tenderness at the sternoclavicular or acromioclavicular joints.
- Hand grips: Good.

Neurovascular:
- Capillary refill: Less than 3 seconds.
- Sensation: Intact to light touch.

RESULTS
Imaging

X-ray of the left shoulder: No fractures identified.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Left shoulder pain - likely rotator cuff tendinopathy.
- Medical Reasoning: The patient's symptoms and physical exam findings are consistent with an injury to the tendons of the shoulder muscles.
- Additional Testing: Order an MRI of the left shoulder to further evaluate the injury.
- Treatment: Refer the patient to physical therapy for 6-8 weeks and continue Tylenol for pain relief. If symptoms do not improve, consider a steroid injection for the shoulder.

Patient Education: The nurse will provide educational materials on physical therapy and what to expect during the treatment process.

Follow-up: Schedule a follow-up visit after the completion of physical therapy.

The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

Chief Complaint:

Left knee pain.

History of Present Illness:

Ms. Russell is a 39-year-old female who presents today for evaluation of severe left knee pain. She states that the pain occurs occasionally, less than once a day, when walking. The pain comes and goes quickly. She has been taking ibuprofen every 6 hours, but it does not help. She denies any numbness or tingling in her leg.

Past Medical History:

Gallstones, managed with Pepcid.
Lumbar fusion surgery 6 years ago.

Social History:

No significant social history.

Medications:

Pepcid, Metformin, Lisinopril, Hydrochlorothiazide, Amlodipine, Farxiga.

Allergies:

No known drug allergies.

Physical Exam:

Vital signs: BP 122/70, HR 72, RR 16, Temp 98.2°F.
Heart: Regular rate and rhythm, 2/6 systolic ejection murmur at left base.
Lungs: Clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Left knee: No ecchymosis, edema, or effusion. No pain to palpation. No decreased range of motion. Negative varus and valgus test.

Results:

Left knee X-ray: No evidence of fracture or bony abnormality.

Assessment:

1. Left knee pain, likely due to arthritis.
2. Hypertension.
3. Diabetes mellitus.

Plan:

1. Prescribe Meloxicam 15 mg daily for left knee pain. Consider physical therapy to strengthen muscles around the knee.
2. Continue Lisinopril 20 mg daily for hypertension. Order echocardiogram to evaluate heart murmur.
3. Order Hemoglobin A1C and lipid panel to assess diabetes management and potential adjustments to Metformin.

Follow-up:

Schedule an appointment for an echocardiogram. Follow up in the clinic after the test results are available.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Chest pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Roger Nelson is a 62-year-old male who presents for emergency room follow-up for chest pain. The patient was doing yard work over the weekend when he began to feel short of breath and a full chest pain for approximately hour. He denies a history of chest pain. The patient notes that after he finished he felt fine. He has not had any other symptoms since that time. He denies a family history of heart disease.

The patient underwent right knee surgery a couple of months ago and has been feeling well since then. He has been in rehab and recovery. He denies chest pain while doing exercises in physical therapy for his knee.

His blood pressure was noted to be 180/95 mmHg when he visited the emergency room. He notes that his blood pressure has not been as high as usual.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

Neck
• General Examination: I do feel a little large thyroid that is not tender. She has a carotid bruit on the right side. 

Respiratory
• Auscultation of Lungs: Clear bilaterally. Cardiovascular
• Auscultation of Heart: Regular rate and rhythm, but I do hear 3/6 systolic ejection murmur. Gastrointestinal
• Examination of Abdomen: Soft. There is a healed scar on the right knee from prior knee surgery. Musculoskeletal
• Examination: There is no lower extremity edema.

RESULTS

Blood pressure is elevated.

EKG is normal.

Echocardiogram demonstrates decreased ejection fraction.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

The patient is a 62-year-old male who presents for emergency room follow-up. He presented to the emergency room for chest pain and elevated blood pressure of 180/95. His EKG from the emergency room was normal, but ejection fraction on echocardiogram was abnormal. His blood pressure today was still elevated.

Chest pain and hypertension.
• Medical Reasoning: Given his recent episode of blood pressure elevation and chest pain, I suspect an element of coronary artery disease as well as pumping dysfunction.
• Medical Treatment: We will change his blood pressure regimen to carvedilol 25 mg twice a day. He should also continue lisinopril 10 mg a day and I want to see how his blood pressure does on that regimen. I also recommended cardiac catheterization on him to make sure that he does not have any blockages in his heart.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Low immunoglobulin A level.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Kyle is a 59-year-old male who presents for evaluation of a low immunoglobulin A level. He reports frequent colds in the wintertime that seem to linger for a long time but is unsure if this is more than usual. He denies any abdominal infections or diarrhea. He has a recent diagnosis of type 2 diabetes and is on metformin. He denies any history of blood transfusions or blood products.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: No fevers, chills.
• Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain or dyspnea on exertion.
• Respiratory: Positive for frequent colds in the wintertime.
• Gastrointestinal: Denies abdominal pain or diarrhea.
• Musculoskeletal: Denies joint pain or muscle aches.
• Neurological: Denies dizziness or lightheadedness.
• Psychiatric: Denies anxiety or depression.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Constitutional: In no apparent distress.
• Neck: Supple without thyromegaly or lymphadenopathy.
• Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
• Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs, gallops, or rubs.
• Abdominal: Soft, non-tender, and non-distended.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Kyle is a 59-year-old male who presents for evaluation of a low immunoglobulin A level.

IgA deficiency.
• Medical Reasoning: Patient has a history of frequent colds in the wintertime but denies any significant infections or complications. Low likelihood of other immunodeficiencies.
• Additional Testing: Order additional blood work to check other antibody levels.
• Patient Education and Counseling: Instruct the patient to watch for infections that do not resolve or are difficult to control, and any changes in abdominal symptoms. Inform the patient to notify healthcare providers of IgA deficiency if blood products are needed in the future.

Diabetes Type II.
• Medical Reasoning: Patient has a recent diagnosis and is on metformin.
• Medical Treatment: Continue metformin as prescribed and monitor blood glucose levels at home.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right elbow pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Lawrence is a patient who presents with right elbow pain for the past 4 days. He reports that he has been doing a lot of pottery during the pandemic, and the pain started after engaging in this activity. The pain is located on the inside of his right elbow and sometimes radiates down into his forearm. He denies any trauma or previous injury to the right elbow. The pain is rated as 6/10 in intensity and has been causing difficulty in lifting and performing daily activities. The pain also keeps him up at night. He has tried ibuprofen for pain relief, which provided minimal relief.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

None reported.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Occupation: Not reported.
Smoking: Not reported.

FAMILY HISTORY

Not reported.

MEDICATIONS

None.

ALLERGIES

None reported.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

Vitals: Within normal limits.
Musculoskeletal: Positive for pain to palpation and moderate tenderness of the medial epicondyle of the right elbow. Positive for pain with pronation of the forearm. Positive for pain with resistance against flexion of the left wrist.

RESULTS

X-ray of the right elbow: No fracture or bony abnormality identified.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

The patient presents with right elbow pain, consistent with medial epicondylitis, likely due to overuse and potential damage of the tendons that bend the wrist towards the palm.

1. Medial epicondylitis:
   - Medical Treatment: Rest the elbow and wear a sling while awake. Apply ice to the elbow for 20 minutes three times a day. Take ibuprofen 600 mg every 6 hours with food for one week.
   - Activity modification: Hold off on pottery work for the next couple of weeks.
   - Follow-up: Schedule a follow-up appointment in one week to assess progress.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Chest pain, shortness of breath, and fall.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

David is a middle-aged male who presents with a recent episode of chest pain, shortness of breath, and a fall. He reports experiencing chest pain while walking outside, which he initially dismissed as heartburn. He also experienced shortness of breath but did not consider it significant. David has a history of hypertension and has been prescribed Bumex, Cozaar, and Norvasc. He admits to not consistently taking his medications and having a poor diet, including salty foods like chips.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Hypertension.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Former smoker, currently smokes occasionally (approximately once per week).

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

No significant changes in sleep patterns. No jugular venous distention. Trace edema in lower extremities.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Blood pressure: 128/72
Heart: 2/6 systolic ejection murmur, stable
Lungs: Clear bilaterally

ASSESSMENT

1. Chest pain and shortness of breath - likely related to dietary indiscretion and uncontrolled hypertension.
2. Hypertension - uncontrolled.

PLAN

1. Continue Bumex 2 mg once daily, Cozaar 100 mg daily, and Norvasc 5 mg once daily. Encourage patient to take medications consistently.
2. Consult with nutritionist to improve diet and reduce salt intake.
3. Obtain a home blood pressure cuff and monitor blood pressure regularly.
4. Order renal artery ultrasound to rule out any underlying issues.
5. Encourage patient to weigh themselves daily and report any significant weight gain (3 pounds in 2 days).

INSTRUCTIONS

1. Take medications as prescribed.
2. Schedule an appointment with a nutritionist.
3. Purchase a home blood pressure cuff and monitor blood pressure regularly.
4. Purchase a scale and weigh yourself daily.
5. Call the clinic with any concerns or significant changes in weight or blood pressure.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right-sided abdominal pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Russell is a patient who presents with sharp pain on the right side of his abdomen below his ribs for the last several days. The pain moves to his lower abdomen and into his groin. The pain is intermittent and severe when it occurs. He reports burning sensation during urination and dark-colored urine. He has taken Tylenol for pain, but it has not provided relief. The patient has a history of kidney stones and a family history of kidney stones in his father.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Abdomen: No tenderness to palpation, no rebound or guarding, no peritoneal signs. Positive CVA tenderness on the right flank.

RESULTS

CT scan of Abdomen: 0.5 cm kidney stone located in the proximal right ureter. No evidence of hydronephrosis.

ASSESSMENT

Acute nephrolithiasis (kidney stone).

PLAN

1. Encourage increased fluid intake to facilitate urination and help pass the stone.
2. Prescribe oxycodone 5 mg every 6-8 hours as needed for pain. Continue alternating with Tylenol.
3. Provide a strainer for the patient to strain urine and collect the stone for analysis.
4. Order a basic metabolic panel, urinalysis, and urine culture.
5. Schedule a follow-up appointment in 1-2 weeks to assess symptoms and discuss further treatment options, such as lithotripsy or ureteroscopy, if necessary.
6. Instruct the patient to contact the clinic if symptoms worsen.

INSTRUCTIONS

Return to the clinic in 1-2 weeks or sooner if symptoms worsen.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Nonhealing diabetic foot ulcer.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Nicholas is a 39-year-old male who presents today for evaluation and management of a nonhealing foot ulcer on his right foot. He has had the ulcer for about six weeks, which started as a blister after wearing tight shoes. The patient noticed a foul smell and yellow drainage from the wound. He has been on antibiotics for six days. The patient reports experiencing pain, throbbing, and cramping in his calf muscle. He has also been coughing and having difficulty catching his breath while walking around the house.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
Diabetes.
Diabetic neuropathy.
Nonhealing diabetic foot ulcer.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

Antibiotics (6 days into a 10-day course).

ALLERGIES

No known allergies.

RESULTS

Right foot X-ray: No evidence of osteomyelitis.

Physical Exam: Necrotic wound on the right heel (2x2 cm) with sloughing tissue, cellulitis, and erythemia. No bony exposure. Bilateral palpable femoral and popliteal pulses, non-palpable dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses (present via Doppler).

ASSESSMENT

• Nonhealing diabetic foot ulcer.
• Diabetes.
• Diabetic neuropathy.

PLAN

1. Order a test to check blood supply for the wound.
2. Perform debridement in the office.
3. Obtain a culture and consider different antibiotic therapy based on results.
4. Monitor redness and swelling in the leg and calf pain.
5. Schedule a follow-up appointment in 7 days.
6. Encourage the patient to follow up with his endocrinologist to maintain hemoglobin A1C below 7 and monitor blood sugars closely.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will continue the current antibiotic therapy prescribed by his primary care physician. Once the culture results are obtained, a determination will be made regarding additional or alternative antibiotic therapy. The patient is advised to closely monitor his blood sugars and maintain communication with his endocrinologist.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Tick bite on the right knee.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Richard is a patient with a history of hypertension and diabetes who presents with a tick bite on his right knee. The patient is unsure of when he got the tick bite but has been spending time outdoors, including hunting. The bite has been present for over a week and is causing burning and discomfort. The patient denies any fever, chills, or joint pain other than his typical arthritic pain. He reports feeling generally unwell and experiencing headaches since the tick bite.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Cardiovascular: Patient is taking lisinopril for hypertension and reports blood pressure is under control.
• Endocrine: Patient has diabetes and is taking metformin. He reports blood sugars are running in the 120s.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Cardiovascular: Heart rate and rhythm are regular, no murmurs, rubs, or gallops appreciated.
• Respiratory: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.
• Musculoskeletal: Right knee with erythema, edema, and area of fluctuance. Pain to palpation of the right anterior knee. Full range of motion of the right knee.
• Skin: Bull's-eye rash present over the right knee.

VITALS REVIEWED

• Blood Pressure: 122/70
• Heart Rate: 67
• Temperature: 98.4°F

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Tick bite and possible Lyme disease:
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient presents with a tick bite on the right knee, accompanied by a bull's-eye rash, which raises concern for Lyme disease.
   • Additional Testing: Order Lyme titer and Western blot to confirm the diagnosis.
   • Medical Treatment: Start the patient on doxycycline 100 mg twice a day for three weeks.
   • Patient Education and Counseling: Discuss the possibility of Lyme disease and the importance of completing the antibiotic course.

2. Hypertension:
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient is taking lisinopril and reports blood pressure is under control.
   • Additional Testing: Order a lipid panel to assess cholesterol levels.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue lisinopril 20 mg once a day.

3. Diabetes:
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient is taking metformin and reports blood sugars are running in the 120s.
   • Additional Testing: Order a hemoglobin A1c to assess long-term blood sugar control. Order a basic metabolic panel to monitor kidney function.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue metformin 1000 mg twice a day.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.
